stem: The nurse reviews the clinical data. Select the 3 most likely findings that require immediate intervention based on the client's presentation.

options.text: Increased systolic blood pressure with a widening pulse pressure.
Pupils equal and reactive to light.

sections.title: Situation
sections.content: Client, a 68-year-old male, admitted at 03:00 today after a fall at home. Found by his daughter. Complains of a severe headache. GCS is fluctuating.

sections.title: Background
sections.content: History of hypertension, managed with lisinopril. No known allergies. CT scan at 04:00 revealed a small subdural hematoma. Neurosurgeon consulted.

sections.title: Assessment
sections.content: 07:00: Client is increasingly lethargic. Vital signs trending towards Cushing's triad. Pupils are now sluggishly reactive on the left. Motor strength decreased in right upper and lower extremities.

sections.title: Recommendation
sections.content: Stat neurosurgical consult. Prepare for possible transfer to ICU. Consider mannitol administration per neurosurgeon order. Continuous monitoring of ICP and neurological status is essential. Frequent vital sign checks q15 minutes.

sections.title: Recent Vitals
sections.content: 06:00: BP 160/80, HR 60, RR 14 and irregular, Temp 37.2°C. SpO2 96% on room air. 06:30: BP 170/70, HR 55, RR 12 and irregular, Temp 37.3°C. SpO2 95% on room air. 07:00: BP 180/60, HR 50, RR 10 and irregular, Temp 37.4°C. SpO2 94% on room air.

sections.title: Lab Results
sections.content: Na: 140 mEq/L, K: 4.0 mEq/L, Cl: 100 mEq/L, Glucose: 110 mg/dL, WBC: 8,000/mm3, Platelets: 200,000/mm3. Coagulation studies pending.

sections.title: Neurological Exam
sections.content: GCS: Eyes 3, Verbal 4, Motor 5. PERRLA except left pupil sluggish. Right-sided weakness. Positive Babinski on the right.

sections.title: Physician Orders
sections.content: Continuous cardiac monitoring. Neurological checks every 15 minutes. CT head stat. Elevate head of bed to 30 degrees. Oxygen per nasal cannula to maintain SpO2 > 92%. Insert foley catheter. Strict I&O. Mannitol 0.25-1 g/kg IV bolus if signs of increased ICP, contact neurosurgeon.

sections.title: Medication Administration Record
sections.content: Lisinopril 10mg PO daily at 08:00. Last dose given at 08:10 today. PRN orders: Acetaminophen 650mg PO q4hr for headache, last given at 04:00.

rationale.option_1: Correct. Increased systolic blood pressure with widening pulse pressure is a key component of Cushing's triad, indicating increasing intracranial pressure.
rationale.option_2: Correct. Decreased heart rate (bradycardia) is another vital sign change associated with Cushing's triad and increased ICP.
rationale.option_3: Correct. Irregular respiratory patterns, such as Cheyne-Stokes respirations, are indicative of pressure on the brainstem and are a component of Cushing's triad.
rationale.option_4: Incorrect. Pupils equal and reactive to light are normal findings and do not indicate increased ICP. Sluggish or non-reactive pupils are more concerning.
rationale.option_5: Incorrect. Increased body temperature is not typically associated with Cushing's triad. It may indicate infection or other systemic issues, but it's not a primary sign of increasing ICP.
rationale.option_6: Incorrect. Decreased diastolic blood pressure, along with increased systolic pressure, leads to a widened pulse pressure, but diastolic pressure alone decreasing is not indicative of Cushing's triad.
rationale.option_7: Incorrect. A mild headache is a common symptom, but in the context of potential increased ICP, the vital sign changes are more indicative of the emergent situation.

clinicalPearls: Cushing's triad (hypertension with widening pulse pressure, bradycardia, and irregular respirations) is a late and ominous sign of increased intracranial pressure. Prompt recognition and intervention are crucial to prevent further neurological damage.
questionTrap: The trap in this question is focusing solely on the neurological exam and overlooking the importance of vital sign trends. While changes in pupillary response and motor function are important, the vital sign changes of Cushing's triad indicate imminent danger.
mnemonic: Cushing's Triad: Think 'Pressure' - P: Pressure (Increased Systolic BP), R: Rate (Decreased Heart Rate), R: Respirations (Irregular).
